1.1.0.desc: Using software tools to browse the web
1.1.1: Accessing the web using the common features of web browsers
1.1.2: Using hyperlinks to access a range of resources on the web
1.1.4: Recognizing the visual cues in everyday web services
1.1.5: Using browser add-ons and extensions to provide additional functionality
1.2.1: Using and understanding the differences between URLs, IP addresses and search terms
1.2.2: Managing information from various sources on the web
1.2.3: Demonstrating the difference between the results of varying search strategies
1.3.0.desc: Locating information, people and resources via the web
1.3.1: Using keywords, search operators, and keyboard shortcuts to make web searches more efficient
1.3.2: Finding real-time or time-sensitive information using a range of search techniques
1.3.3: Locating or finding desired information within search results
1.4.0.desc: Critically evaluating information found on the web
1.4.1: Making judgments based on technical and design characteristics to assess the credibility of information
1.4.2: Researching authorship and ownership of websites and their content
1.4.3: Comparing information from a number of sources to judge the trustworthiness of content
1.4.4: Discriminating between 'original' and derivative web content
1.5.0.desc: Keeping systems, identities, and content safe
1.5.1: Detecting online scams and 'phishing' by employing recognized tools and techniques
1.5.2: Encrypting data and communications using software and add-ons
1.5.3: Changing the default behavior of websites, add-ons and extensions to make web browsing more secure
2.1.0.desc: Creating and curating content for the web
2.1.1: Inserting hyperlinks into a web page
2.1.2: Embedding multimedia content into a web page
2.1.3: Creating web resources in ways appropriate to the medium/genre
2.2.0.desc: Modifying existing web resources to create something new
2.2.3: Creating something new on the web using existing resources
2.3.0.desc: Creating universally effective communications through web resources
2.3.1: Identifying the different parts of a web page using industry-recognized terms
2.3.2: Improving the accessibility of a web page by modifying its color scheme and markup
2.3.3: Iterating on a design after feedback from a target audience
2.3.4: Reorganizing the structure of a web page to improve its hierarchy conceptual flow
2.3.5: Demonstrating the difference between inline, embedded and external CSS
2.4.0.desc: Creating interactive experiences on the web
2.4.1: Explaining the differences between client-side and server-side scripting
2.4.3: Reading and explaining the structure of code
2.4.5: Adding code comments for clarification and attribution
2.5.1: Understanding and labeling the web stack
2.5.2: Explaining the differences between the web and the Internet
2.5.3: Exporting and backing up your data from web services
2.5.4: Moving the place(s) where your data is hosted on the web
2.5.5: Securing your data against malware and computer criminals
3.1.0.desc: Jointly creating and providing access to web resources
3.1.1: Sharing a resource using an appropriate tool and format for the audience
3.1.2: Tracking changes made to co-created web resources
3.1.3: Choosing a web tool to use for a particular contribution/collaboration
3.1.5: Configuring notifications to keep up to date with community spaces and interactions
3.1.6: Using synchronous and asynchronous tools to communicate with web communities, networks and groups
3.2.0.desc: Getting involved in web communities and understanding their practices
3.2.2: Using constructive criticism in a group or community setting
3.2.3: Configuring settings within tools used by online communities
3.2.4: Participating in both synchronous and asynchronous discussions
3.2.5: Expressing opinions appropriately in web discussions
3.2.6: Defining different terminology used within online communities
3.3.0.desc: Examining the consequences of sharing data online
3.3.1: Identifying rights retained and removed through user agreements
3.3.2: Taking steps to secure non-encrypted connections
3.3.3: Explaining ways in which computer criminals are able to gain access to user information
3.3.4: Managing the digital footprint of an online persona
3.3.5: Identifying and taking steps to keep important elements of identity private
3.4.0.desc: Helping to keep the web democratic and universally accessible
3.4.1: Distinguishing between open and closed licensing
3.4.2: Making web resources available under an open license
3.4.3: Using and sharing files in open, web-friendly formats when appropriate
3.4.4: Contributing to an Open Source project
